subject: RE: [junit] JNI (Shudder!)
msgSnippet: To rule out the effects of JUnit, try running a class with that code without JUnit. If you have the same problem then its not the fault of JUnit. ... Mike
messageBody:
To rule out the effects of JUnit, try running a class with that code
without JUnit. If you have the same problem then its not the fault of
JUnit.

-----------------------------
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The Object Testing Company
www.javatesting.com
**********************************
* Makers of "Test Mentor" *
* and "Enhanced JUnit" Java *
* component testing tools *
**********************************

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, August 12, 2003 2:05 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] JNI (Shudder!)
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > Where is the *.dll in relation to the location of the
> *.class file on
> > the file system?
> > The only thing that's different, it appears, is the *.dll's path
> relative to the *.class file.
> >
> > Is the *.dll picked up through the system PATH?
> >
>
> The DLL is located via the system PATH. Just for grins, I've tried
> mirroring the directory structure for the DLL with the package
> structure. Alas, I'm still stumped.
>
> OK, there has to be an application out there using JNI under the hood
> somewhere that's also being unit tested with JUnit. I can't convince
> myself it's a bug with JUnit.
>
> Mike
>
> --
> Mike Clark
> http://clarkware.com
> (303) 589-3812
>
